column1: The name Quimper comes from the Breton kemper
Quimper is the ancient capital of Cornouaille
column3: and has a distinctive Breton Celtic character.  Its name is the Breton word kemper (cognate to Welsh cymer)
column4: meaning "confluence".  The town developed at the confluence of the rivers Le Steir and L'Odet. Shops and flags celebrate the region's Celtic heritage.

column1: Quimper was originally settled during Roman times. By AD 495
column2: the town had become a Bishopric. It subsequently became the capital of the counts of Cornouailles. In the eleventh century
column3: it was united with the Duchy of Brittany.  During the War of the Breton Succession (1341–64)
column4: the town suffered considerable ruin. In 1364
column5: the duchy passed to the House of Montfort.

column1: The town has a rustic atmosphere
column2: with footbridges spanning the rivers that flow through it. The Church of Locmaria
column4: dates from the eleventh century.  The Cathedral of Saint-Corentin
column6: was constructed between the thirteenth and sixteenth centuries.  It is the oldest Gothic structure in lower Brittany. Its two towers are 76 m (250 feet); its spires were added in the nineteenth century.  The fifteenth-century stained glass windows are exceptional. The cathedral is dedicated to Quimper's first bishop

column1: The town's best known product is Quimper faience
column2: tin-glazed pottery. It has been made here since 1690
column3: using bold provincial designs of Jean-Baptiste Bousquet. Quimper has a museum devoted to faience. The town’s eating establishments boast some of the best crêpes and cider in Brittany.  The town has also been known for copper and bronze work
